natural problem: What is the constant term in the expansion of $(x^4+x+5)(x^5+x^3+15)$?
natural solution: We only need to look at the constant terms; all the other terms will have variables in them when multiplied.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 + x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 5 + x powr 3 + 15"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x * Q x = (x powr 9 + x powr 7 + x powr 5 + x powr 4 + x powr 2 + 75)"
shows  "75 = (\<Sum> n \<in> {0}. coeff (P x * Q x) n)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the constant term in the expansion of $(x^4+x+5)(x^5+x^3+15)$? The final Answer is 75
 ### Proof
 We only need to look at the constant terms; all the other terms will have variables in them when multiplied.
 Thus we have $(5)(15)$, which equals $\boxed{75}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 + x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 5 + x powr 3 + 15"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x * Q x = (x powr 9 + x powr 7 + x powr 5 + x powr 4 + x powr 2 + 75)"
shows  "75 = (\<Sum> n \<in> {0}. coeff (P x * Q x) n)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two functions, $P(x) = x^4 + x + 5$ and $Q(x) = x^5 + x^3 + 15$, and their product $P(x)Q(x) = x^9 + x^7 + x^5 + x^4 + x^2 + 75$. What is the sum of the coefficients of terms with degree 0 in $P(x)Q(x)$? The final answer is 75.

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 + x + 5"

shows  "5 * 15 = 75"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 + x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 5 + x powr 3 + 15"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x * Q x = x powr 9 + x powr 8 + 20 * x powr 7 + 20 * x powr 6 + 75 * x powr 5 + 75 * x powr 4 + 75 * x powr 3 + 75 * x powr 2 + 75 * x + 75"
shows  "75 = (THE c. \<exists> x. P x * Q x = c)"
a_2.formal solution:

 ### Proof

 *)

shows  "75 = (THE c. \<exists> x. P x * Q x = c)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 + x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 5 + x powr 3 + 15"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x * Q x = x powr 9 + x powr 7 + 15 * x powr 4 + x powr 6 + x powr 4 + 15 * x + 75"
shows  "75 = (GREATEST c. \<exists> x P Q. P x * Q x = x powr 9 + x powr 7 + 15 * x powr 4 + x powr 6 + x powr 4 + 15 * x + c)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = x^4 + x + 5$ and $Q(x) = x^5 + x^3 + 15$, find the largest possible constant term $c$ in the expression $P(x) * Q(x) = x^9 + x^7 + 15x^4 + x^6 + x^4 + 15x + c$. The final answer is $75$.
